subsection.title: An Isolated Charged Metallic Sphere
subsection.p: Consider an isolated metallic sphere of radius R that has a total excess charge +q placed on it. The entire charge +q on the metallic sphere will end up at the surface as shown in . Furthermore, as there are no other charges or bodies around, the charge distribution on the spherical surface will be spherically symmetric.

Aside Note: If there were other objects in the neighborhood of the metallic sphere, then the charges on the surface of the sphere will not necessarily be spherically symmetric - there will be more charges in certain direction than in other directions.

The electric field outside the charged spherical conductor is indistinguishable from that of a point charge +q placed at the center without the conductor present. The difference between the charged metal and a point charge occurs only at the space points inside the conductor: for a point charge placed at the center of the sphere, the electric field will not be zero at points of space occupied by the sphere, but for a conductor with the same amount of charge has a zero electric field at those points. However, there is no distinction at the outside points in space where r > R, and we can replace the isolated charged spherical conductor by a point charge at its center with impunity.

p.alert: Electric Potential of a Charged Metallic Sphere

subsection.p: We find electric potential at a point P by integrating negative of the dot product of electric field with displacement from r=\infty (reference point) to the r=r.

subsection.title: An Isolated Charged Long Metallic Wire

sidebyside.p:
We have already worked out electric field of a charged wire of linear charge density \lambda. Using Gauss's law for cylindrical symmetry, it was shown that electric field has the following magnitude at a ditance s from the wire.
E = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\;\frac{1}{s}.

subsection.p:
The electric potential with potential zero reference at distance s_\text{ref} is
\phi = - \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\;\ln\frac{s}{s_\text{ref}}.

exercise.title: Electric Field of Charged Copper Cylinder

statement.p: A long cylinder of copper of radius 3\text{ cm} is charged so that it has a uniform charge per unit length on its surface of 3\;\mu\text{C/m}. (a) Find the electric field inside (s=2.0\text{ cm}) and outside (s=4.0\text{ cm}) the cylinder. (b) Draw electric field lines in a plane perpendicular to the rod.

hint.p: (a) Use formula for electric field for cylindrical symmetry. (b) Use the rule that: (1) Electric field lines begin at positive charge and end at negative charges and (2) Electric field lines land perpendicularly on metals.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) Since, we have electrostatic situation, charges on metal will reside on the surface of the cylinder. Using the Gaussâ€™s law for cylindrical symmetry, you find that electric field inside the cylinder is zero.
E_\text{in} = 0.
From using Gauss's law for a point outside we will get
E_\text{out} = \frac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\;\frac{1}{s},
where s is the distance of the point from the center of the rod.
at points outside the cylinder, the magnitude E_{\text{out}} of electric field is dependent on the distance s meters from the axis of the cylinder.
E_{\text{out}} \amp = \frac{1}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\:\frac{\lambda}{s} = 2k\:\frac{\lambda}{s} \amp = 2\times 9\times 10^{9}\:\dfrac{\text{N.m}^2}{\text{C}^2}\times \dfrac{3\times 10^{-6}\:\text{C/m}}{0.04\:\text{m}} = 1.35\times 10^6 \:\text{N/C}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: shows electric field lines and equi-potential lines (dashed) in a cross-section of the wire.

exercise.title: Electric Potential between two Charged Metal Plates

statement.p: Two large charged aluminum plates of charge density \pm 30\text{ mC/m}^2 face each other at a separation of 5\text{ mm}. (a) Find the electric potential everywhere. (b) An electron is released from rest at the negative plate, with what speed will it strike the positive plate?

hint.p: (a) Electric field between plates is constant. (b) Use conservation of energy.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) The electric field between the plates is constant with magnitude E = \sigma/\epsilon_0 directed from the positive plate to the negative plate. Therefore the electric potential between the plates increases linearly from zero on the negative plate to \phi = (\sigma/\epsilon_0)\:d on the positive plate, where d is the separation of plates. The numerical value of the potential difference will be
\phi = \frac{30\times 10^{-3}\:\text{C/m}^2}{8.85\times 10^{-12}\:\text{C}^2/\text{N.m}^2}\:0.005\:\text{m} = 1.69\times 10^7\:\text{V},
where I have written the final unit as volts since that is what the combination of the other units is called in SI units.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) Using the conservation of energy we find
\frac{1}{2} mv^2 = |e\: \phi|
Hence,
v \amp = \sqrt{2|e\: \phi|/m} \amp = \sqrt{2\times 1.6\times 10^{-19}\:\text{C}\times 1.69\times 10^7\:\text{V}/1.67\times 10^{-27}\:\text{kg}} \amp = 5.7\times 10^7\:\text{m/s},
which is about 1/5th of the speed of light in vacuum. You should probably use relativistic formulas.

exercise.title: Charge and Voltage of a Gold Shell Surrounding a Charged Pith Ball

statement.p: A small spherical pith ball of radius 0.5\text{ cm} is painted with a silver paint and then -10\ \text{nC} of charge placed on it. The charged pith ball is put at the center of a gold spherical shell of inner radius 2.0\text{ cm} and outer radius 2.2\text{ cm}.
(a) Find the electric potential of the gold shell with respect to zero potential at infinity.
(b) How much charge should you put on the gold shell if you want to make its potential 100\text{ V}?

hint.p: (a) Outside the spherical gold shell, formula for potential is same as that of a point charge located at the origin. (b) Set up the condition for potential at outer surface of gold shell.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a)
Outside the gold shell, the potential will be given by the same formula as that of a point charge at the center. Therefore,
\phi \amp = \dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\: \dfrac{q}{R} \amp = 9\times 10^9\:\text{N.m}^2\text{/C}^2\times\dfrac{-10\times 10^{-9}\:\text{C}}{0.022\:\text{m}} = - 4.1\times 10^{3}\;\text{V}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) To make the potential of the gold shell 100\text{ V}, we must put positive charge Q on the shell such that its potential and that of the charges on the pith ball together equal 100\text{ V}. This gives the following condition on Q.
9\times 10^{9}\:\text{N.m}^2\text{/C}^2\times\dfrac{-10\times 10^{-9}\:\text{C} + Q}{0.022\:\text{m}} = 100\:\text{V}.
When you solve this equation for Q you get
Q = \left[ 10\times 10^{-9} + 2.44\times 10^{-10} \right]\: \text{C} = 10.244\text{ nC}.

exercise.title: Electric Field and Electric Potential of a Charged Aluminum Cylinder

statement.p: A long cylinder of aluminum of radius R is charged so that it has a uniform charge per unit length on its surface of \lambda. (a) Find the electric field inside and outside the cylinder. (b) Find the electric potential inside and outside the cylinder. (c) Plot electric field and electric potential as a function of distance from the center of the rod.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) By Gauss's law, you can show that E_{\textrm{in}} = 0, and E_{\textrm{out}} is given by the following.
E_{\textrm{out}} = \dfrac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\: \dfrac{1}{s},\ \ \ (s>R)
The direction of the elctric field is (cylindrical) radially out from the axis of the cylinder if \lambda \gt 0 and towards the axis if \lambda \lt 0.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) The electric potential at a field point can be obtained by integrating electric field from a reference point a distance s_{\textrm{ref}} from the axis to the field point. For simplicity we can pick s_{\textrm{ref}} = R so that potential at the surface of the cylinder will be zero. In this case we get integrating the electric field from s=R to s \gt R, we get
\phi_{\textrm{out}} = -\dfrac{\lambda}{2\pi\epsilon_0}\: \ln\dfrac{s}{R}\ \ (s\ge R).
The electric potential inside does not change from that at the outer surface of the metal since electric field in the body of the aluminum cylinder is zero. Hence,
\phi_{\textrm{in}} = 0\ \ (s\le R).
